Today’s chemists heavily rely on many advanced characterization techniques such as optical, X-ray, and electron microscopy, and various types of spectroscopy, to piece together the pictures of the microscopic world.[19] Among these techniques, solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (SSNMR) has a remarkable strength and it is an ideal tool for probing short-range ordering and dynamics (Figure 1). However, in many relevant studies, SSNMR characterizations are often absent or have not been utilized to the fullest due to the limited accessibility, and, more prevailingly, the lack of acquaintance in the
nanomaterials community. As we foresee growing interest in the fundamental chemistry of nanomaterials, especially about the interfacial structures and phenomena, here we stress the unique characterization capabilities of SSNMR and its universality in different systems.
Magnetic resonance originates from the interactions between an external magnetic field and nuclei that possess a nonzero spin quantum number, including 1H, 2H, 6Li, 7Li, 13C, 14N, 15N, 17O, 19F etc. The electronic structures, the internuclear distances, and the molecular dynamics are embedded in the strength and anisotropy of the nuclei’s chemical shift, the dipolar coupling, and the quadrupolar coupling (for spin > 1/2), as well as the relaxation behavior (Figure 2). NMR spectroscopists extract critical chemical and structural information through ingeniously designed pulse sequences and wellengineered apparatus.[20–26] In general, the superior strength of SSNMR is manifested in three ways. Firstly, SSNMR can achieve high spectroscopic resolution and can therefore simultaneously qualify and quantify the chemical compositions; secondly, SSNMR has a spatial resolution at the atomic scale and hence can provide key structural and conformational information; thirdly, SSNMR can assess dynamic behaviors across a wide range of timescales, thus revealing the mechanisms of intermolecular interactions, chemical reactions and transport phenomena. On top of these three strengths, SSNMR is a nondestructive method that can investigate the interfaces in their pristine state with minimal interference, and in many cases experiments may be performed in situ or in operando.[27–30] Many SSNMR pulse sequences established in the study of macromolecules[20,23,31] are equally useful in the nanomaterials world. The recent development of signal-enhancement methods, such as dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) at high magnetic fields,[32–34] show also great promise in the study of
Surface and interfacial chemistry is of fundamental importance in functional nanomaterials applied in catalysis, energy storage and conversion, medicine, and other nanotechnologies. It has been a perpetual challenge for the scientific community to get an accurate and comprehensive picture of the structures, dynamics, and interactions at interfaces. Here, some recent examples in the major disciplines of nanomaterials are selected (e.g., nanoporous materials, battery materials, nanocrystals and quantum dots, supramolecular assemblies, drug-delivery systems, ionomers, and graphite oxides) and it is shown how interfacial chemistry can be addressed through the perspective of solid-state NMR characterization techniques.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Interfaces are critical in determining the properties and functionalities of nanomaterials.[1–3] They govern the extrinsic activity, stability, and responsiveness for functional materials, such as nanoporous materials,[4,5] nanocrystals and quantum dots,[6,7] battery materials,[8,9] medicines,[10] supramolecular assemblies,[7,11–13] and soft matters.[14,15] Interfaces usually consist of disorder and defects, and involve multiple phases and diverse molecular components. It has been a daunting task for material scientists to comprehend the complexity of interfacial structures and the interplay of their constituents.[16–18]

Surface and interfacial phenomena embody a huge part of chemistry.[16,18] Here, we select several representative systems, including nanoporous materials, nanocrystals, nanomaterials for lithium batteries and medicine, hybrid assemblies, ionomers, and graphite oxides. These systems are chosen mainly because they are more familiar to us and also due to the fact that they receive much attention in contemporary research. It is not intended to be a comprehensive review of materials, nevertheless these examples do include many important aspects of interfacial chemistry. For instance, the chemical bonding between different components, the interaction between host and guest molecules, the formation of domains of different sizes or shapes, and the chemical and electrochemical reactions at the interfaces are ubiquitous aspects present in many systems.
We hope that the selected examples will help to elucidate SSNMR approaches, and that researchers can thus address interfacial chemistry from a different angle when encountering challenges in research of nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2. Interfaces in Nanoporous Materials
sections.text: Zeolites and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are two major types of nanoporous materials.[35–37] Both types of materials can be used as excellent heterogeneous catalysts[38–40] and molecular sieves.[41–43] Zeolites, made from metals and silicates, are generally more stable under harsh conditions; while MOFs, constructed with metal clusters and organic linkers, allow more flexibility in controlling their functionalities and pore sizes. For heterogeneous catalysis, the key processes, including the diffusion and adsorption of reactants, the conversion of chemical bonds, the formation of products, etc., all happen at the solid– liquid or solid–gas interface.[18,44] The interfacial host–guest interaction is also the primary element for applications in molecular separation, capture, storage, and so on.[45,46] In the following subsections, we will show that SSNMR is a superb characterization tool for addressing the fundamental chemistry in these nanoporous systems.[47,48]

sections.heading: 2.1. Characterization of Active Centers
sections.text:
The active centers in nanoporous materials play essential roles in catalytic events and adsorption processes.[18] The detection of metal species at active centers such as 25Mg, 49Ti, 67Zn, 95Mo, and 91Zr has been hindered by their low gyromagnetic ratio (low sensitivity) and large quadrupolar interaction. Nowadays, the use of high-field NMR spectrometers facilitates the SSNMR detection of metal centers in MOFs and zeolites.[49–51] Huang’s group has performed a series of studies on metal centers in MOFs using a 21.1 T high-field SSNMR spectrometer.[52,53] They applied 25Mg NMR to study the local binding environment of magnesium centers in MOFs.[52] In CPO-27-Mg (also known as Mg-MOF-74), the electric-field gradient parameters were combined with density functional theory (DFT) calculations to deduce the MgO distances and OMgO bond angles under dehydration or rehydration conditions.[54] In the α-Mg3(HCOO)6 sample, four Mg sites were identified with 25Mg SPAM 3QMAS (soft-pulse-added-mixing triple-quantum magic-angle spinning) experiments (see Figure 3). sections.heading: 2.2. Host–Guest Interactions in the Pores
sections.text:
One of the promising applications for MOFs is in CO2 capture and storage.[63] SSNMR has made significant contributions to understanding the dynamics of CO2 in MOF materials and how it interacts with the host matrix.[48] The following series of studies by different groups represents a nice example of how scientific understanding can be gradually refined and enriched through investigation from multiple angles. In 2012, Kong et al. carried out a variable-temperature NMR investigation of CO2 adsorbed in Mg-MOF-74, a MOF with Mg2+ open metal sites.[64] The 13C signal of CO2 takes on a motional-averaged powder pattern as shown in Figure 5. Because of the linear geometry of the CO2 molecules, this kind of powder-pattern profile unambiguously corresponds to a uniaxial rotation. Based on this observation, Kong et al.[64] proposed a model in which CO2 undergoes uniaxial rotation at the fixed point of the Mg2+ open metal sites. However, this original model was challenged by Lin et al.[65]
based on their Monte Carlo simulations (Figure 6), which found that, at room temperature, CO2 molecules can have multi-site hopping instead of single-site rotation. It emerged that the multi-site hopping model can also account for the 13C NMR pattern due to symmetry of the hexagonal pore space. The changes of 13C lineshape with respect to temperature can be understood as a result of translational motion. The newly modified model not only explained the 13C NMR of CO2 in Mg-MOF-74, but also predicted the experimental results performed on CO2 in a similar structure of Mg2(dobpdc), a MOF-74-type MOF with an extended organic linker. The dynamics study was continued by Wang et al., who measured the 17O NMR of 17O-labeled CO2 in Mg-MOF-74.[66] The central transition of the 17O signal is an even more sensitive probe of CO2 dynamics. The fitting of the variable temperature patterns (Figure 7) provided solid evidence that both single-site wobbling and multi-site hopping are accountable. The authors also performed the same experiments on Zn-MOF-74 and they concluded a weaker Zn2+–CO2 interaction compared with Mg2+–CO2.

Figure 9 shows the in situ NMR spectra of conversion of methane and carbon dioxide over zinc-modified H–ZSM-5 zeolite at a specified reaction temperature. As shown in Figure 9a, the appearance of zinc methyl species (−20 ppm) and surface carbonate species (163 ppm) indicates the activation of CH4 and CO2 on the catalyst. The formation of acetic acid starts at ≈523 K can be confirmed from the NMR signals at 22 ppm (methyl group) and 186 ppm (carbonyl group). The signal intensity of the zinc methyl species decreases as a consequence of the formation of acetic acid, suggesting the transformation of the zinc methyl species to acetic acid. Further experimental evidence reveals that the zinc sites efficiently activate CH4 to form zinc methyl species, which can be inserted by CO2 to form surface acetate species (–Zn–OOCCH3).
MTO conversion to produce ethylene and propene over acidic zeolites is one of the most important catalytic reactions in C1 chemistry,[74]
which provides an opportunity for producing useful petrochemicals from coal and natural-gas resources. Figure 10 shows the 13C-MAS NMR spectra of 13CH3OH reacted on H-SSZ-13 with time on-stream under continuous-flow conditions.[75] As shown in Figure 10, the appearance of the characteristic peaks at 189/190 ppm and 240–250 ppm indicates the presence of the heptamethylbenzenium-cation (heptaMB+) and the heptamethylcyclopentenyl-cation (pentaMCP+) carbenium-ion intermediates. It is shown that the concentration evolutions of heptaMB+, pentaMCP+ with time on-stream are almost consistent with that of the methanol-conversion variation. It reveals the participation of the heptaMB+ and pentaMCP+ carbenium ions in the MTO reaction as the important intermediates. With the assistance of DFT theoretical calculations, it was concluded that both the paring and side-chain methylation mechanisms are energetically feasible reaction routes, whereas the side-chain methylation mechanism is more predominant due to the lower energy barrier.
A high specific surface area and large density of interfacial nuclei in nanoporous materials are beneficial for SSNMR characterization.[76] These studies enabled in-depth understanding of adsorption and catalytic processes down to the molecular level. Not only can SSNMR supplement common diffraction and microscopy techniques for structural determination, but, more importantly it can probe the dynamic interactions between species. Real-time monitoring of chemical and physical processes at application-relevant conditions is the longpursued goal of NMR spectroscopists. Although it has proved successful in many systems, in situ SSNMR measurements are still quite demanding, as they often require custom modification of sophisticated commercial instrumentation. sections.heading: 3. Interfaces in Materials for Lithium Batteries
sections.text: Due to the increasing use of portable electronics, the need to balance the fluctuating output of renewable energy sources, and the rise of electric vehicles, lithium batteries (LBs) (including Li-ion batteries (LIBs) and Li-metal batteries (LMBs)) have been considered as the most popular portable power sources in the modern time.[8,82,83] Many nanomaterials and nanostructures are being explored, or have already been utilized in current batteries.[9,84–88] The main advantages of these nanomaterials stem from their improved interfacial properties for electrochemical reactions.[85] From a more practical view, it is more important to understand how the interfacial structures and processes in battery systems are influenced by the nanomaterials and nanostructures.[89,90] Multiple interfacial processes occur during the operation of batteries, including the growth of a solid-electrolyte-interphase (SEI) layer, intercalation/deintercalation of Li ions (Li+) in the electrodes, Li+ transportation, and Li deposition on the electrode surface.[91] SSNMR can characterize these phenomena and processes at multiple levels and thereby offer clear guidance for the optimization of nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 3.1. Studies of the Solid Electrolyte Interface
sections.text:
During cycling, the lithium salts and solvents in the electrochemical cells are reduced at a potential higher than the intercalation potential of Li+, resulting in the precipitation of various species on the anode surface to form the SEI layer, which prevents further reaction between the electrolyte and electrodes and ensures the reversible behavior of the insertion and extraction of isolated Li+.[92,93] However, with successive charge cycles, the continuous deposition of the SEI also results in the gradual reduction of capacity, due to the increasing ionic impedance with increasing thickness. Therefore, understanding the formation mechanism and properties of SEI is very important for optimizing the surface structure of electrodes.[94] However, the investigation of the SEI and the cathode/electrolyte interface is a challenging task, due to their dynamic feature during the electrochemical process. SSNMR has been used to probe the chemically bonded environments relevant to the inorganic species, organic molecules, and oligomers of the SEI layer.[94] Up to now, SEI formation on anode materials, such as graphite, disordered carbon, Li4Ti5O12, TiSnSb, MFx/MxOy, LiFeSn2, and Si, etc., has been investigated.[94–100]
In the 2000s, 7Li NMR was used to study the SEI formation.[101–103] In combination of 7Li and 19F MAS NMR, the formation of LiF in the SEI was identified by Meyer et al.[94] The authors found a positive correlation for the amount of LiF at the cathode surface and the percentage of Li loss from the cathode. Recently, 7Li and 13C MAS SSNMR spectra of uncycled, lithiated, and delithiated graphite anodes were studied by
Huff et al.[95] Changes in the chemical shifts of the C–O region to more positive values likely indicates that the terminal groups of the SEI species change from COC to COH groups upon lithiation. Additionally, relaxation measurements indicate that the SEI compounds likely contain long-chain polymeric species with a molecular weight larger than 600 kDa.
NMR investigations have been carried out on newly studied reduced graphene oxide (rGO) electrodes, which have a high surface area, thus allowing enhanced Li+ storage capacity. In these materials, the residual oxygen functional groups such as hydroxyl, epoxy, and carboxylic moieties may interact with Li in addition to the usual intercalation chemistry, resulting in irreversible capacity loss. Recently, Tang et al. elucidated the temporal evolution of the SEI layer on rGO and quantified the amount of trapped lithium by in situ NMR and Raman.[104] Figure 11 shows the in situ 7Li NMR spectra corresponding to specific potential stages (i.e., open-circuit voltage, the end of the discharge, the end of charge, etc.). The spectra can be deconvoluted into three types of species: Li intercalates in the rGO lattice, the electrolyte, and the Li metal in the electrode, as shown in Figure 11b.
Besides anode materials, the components of the SEI layer mainly come from the electrolyte. Electrolyte salts, such as LiPF6, LiAsF6, lithium bis(oxalato)borate (LiBOB), LiClO4, or LiBF4, in a mixture of carbonate solvents are widely used electrolyte solutions.[93] A comparative investigation of the different lithium salts on the formation of the SEI on binderfree graphite anodes for LIBs was conducted by Nie and Lucht[105] The electrolytes investigated include 1 m LiPF6, LiBF4, lithium bis-(trifluoromethane) sulfonimide (LiTFSI), lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl) imide (LiFSI), lithium difluoro(oxalato) borate (LiDFOB), or LiBOB dissolved in ethylene carbonate (EC). Lithium ethylene dicarbonate (LEDC) was observed in the 1H NMR spectra of all the cycled electrolytes. Possible decomposition products including lithium oxalates, boron oxalates, and ethylene oxide complexes of boron are indicated in LiDFOB and LiBOB electrolytes. On the other hand, all of the SEIs except for that generated from LiBOB contain LiF.
Silicon is another attractive anode material because of its extremely high energy density, which is almost ten times higher than that of graphite. Michan and co-workers[106,107] precisely observed the SEI formation from the reduction of a standard 1 m LiPF6 in EC/DMC electrolyte on a Si anode over multi ple electrochemical cycles by way of 7Li, 19F, and 13C SSNMR spectra. The formation of LiF was observed and the amount did not increase significantly after the first cycle, suggesting that LiF is formed mainly in the initial cycle. Additionally, species such as LixPOFy and SiOx′Fy′ were also observed in the EC samples. After subsequent cycles, Li salts like LiF, Li2CO3, ROCO2Li, LiPF6, and possibly LiSiO4 were detected.[106] The presence of lithium ethylene carbonate (LEC), lithium butylene dicarbonate (LBDC), RCO2Li, HCO2Li, Li2CO3, and lithium methyl carbonate (LMC) was then confirmed by single-pulse 13C NMR. The organic SEI composition was further investigated by 2D 13C single quantum/double quantum (SQ/DQ) homonuclear correlation SSNMR experiments as shown in Figure 12. The resonance labeled D is characteristic of the OCH2CH2O oligomers generated by the decomposition of EC.[106]

sections.heading: 3.2. Investigations of Electrochemical Reactions
sections.text:
Electrochemical processes happen as Li+ ions move into the electrodes during insertion (or intercalation). Reversely, ions move back out during extraction (or deintercalation). The local electronic environment of 7Li (and 6Li) can be probed by SSNMR and, consequently, yields information about the Li environment and electrochemically induced structural changes of the electrodes during or after cycling.
In the early steps of SSNMR experiments, the lithiation/ delithiation process in various carbonous materials was investigated.[108–111] The in situ study of graphite provided clear assignments of the 7Li NMR shifts and quadrupolar coupling constants for the different lithiated graphite phases (LiC18, LiC12, LiC6, etc.), which were quite distinct from the two featureless resonances (intercalated and quasi-metallic Li) of the carbon electrode. The methodology was extended to investigate alloying of Li in a Si anode.[112–114] Key and co-workers[112,113] found that the 7Li NMR signals could be used to identify Si environments in semiconducting LixSi phases. 7Li shifts at 10−0, 20−15, and 15−10 ppm were assigned to Li+ near isolated Si atoms, small clusters, and the mixtures of the two, respectively.
As shown in Figure 13, the in situ NMR spectra of Sinanowire–carbon-fiber-based gas-diffusion-layer (SiNW– CFGDL) composite were collected by Ogata et al. under potentiostatic cycling.[114] The cells were held at 0 V in the 1st and
2nd discharges to convert all of the a-LixSi phase to c-Li3.75Si and c-Li3.75+δSi, a process that can be monitored in real time via the complete loss of the P1 (Li nearby small Si clusters) resonance (Figure 13a,b). The NMR signatures of the delithiation processes from a-Li3.5Si to a-Li2.0Si and a-Li2.0Si to a-Si could only be observed when the discharge was stopped at 30 mV (Figure 13c).
7Li NMR has been used to study a large variety of anode materials, such as SiOC,[115] Sn,[116] Ge,[117] Nb2O5,[118] Cu3P,[119] CuF2,[120] and cathode materials like LiMPO4,[121,122] LiMO2,[123,124] and LiFeBO3[125] have been studied. More recently, Pecher et al.[126] developed and explored the use of a new automatic tuning matching cycler (ATMC) in situ NMR probe system to track the formation of intermediate phases and investigate electrolyte decomposition during the electrochemical cycling of LIBs. The new approach addresses many of the issues arising during in situ NMR, e.g., large-range shifts of the multicomponent samples, changes in sample conditions (such as the magnetic susceptibility and conductivity) during cycling, signal broadening due to paramagnetism, as well as the interference between the NMR and the external battery cycling circuit.

The 7Li NMR lineshape can be used to study the mobility of lithium ions. In bulk Li2O samples, 7Li NMR gives a relatively broad Gaussian lineshape, while for superionic conductors in which ions can transport over a long range by fast hopping through adjacent lattice sites, NMR gives a Lorentzian lineshape with a narrow width.[91] When the crystal size of Li2O shrinks down to the nanoscale, the 7Li spectrum showed a new narrow Lorentzian peak, indicating that the ions at the interface have a faster motion than those in the inner grains (Figure 14).[91] Similar phenomena were also observed in nanoscale LiNbO3, LiTiO3, and other materials.[147] In addition to the effect on the width of 7Li NMR spectra, fast transport of ions in materials also influences the relaxation processes, including spin–lattice relaxation (T1), spin–spin relaxation (T2), and spin–lattice relaxation in a rotating coordinate system (T1ρ).[91,127] For example, the atoms in grains in the Li2OAl2O3 composite show a different spin–lattice relaxation time from the atoms at the interface. The fast decay can be attributed to the less mobile ions in the grains, and the slow decay can be attributed to the highly mobile ions in the interfacial regions.[148]
The solid electrolyte is a critical component of solid-state batteries. It is important to understand the state of the Li+ at respective binding sites and how Li+ migrates through the electrolyte and interface. 2D exchange NMR experiments can be used to measure the slow exchange between the Li+ at the different sites. Bottke et al.[149] carried out 6Li 2D exchange MAS NMR spectroscopy to probe the slow Li+ hopping processes in a polycrystalline powder sample of lithium zirconate (Li2ZrO3), as shown in Figure 15. Two signals at −0.10 and 0.26 ppm, with equal intensity, reflect the two magnetically (and electrically) inequivalent Li sites in the Li2ZrO3. Based on the time evolution of 6Li 2D NMR spectra, a Li+ exchange rate of 60 jumps per hour was derived from the off-diagonal intensities. Therefore, Li-ion conductivity of σ ≈ 10−13 to 10−12 S cm−1 at ≈310 K can be obtained according to the Nernst–Einstein equation.
For large-scale translational motion, the apparent self-diffusion coefficient of the Li+ ions and other ionic species can be determined by PFG NMR. Due to the fast molecular exchange in liquids, these diffusion coefficients are weighted averages over single ions, ion pairs, and clusters, in which the particular ion is contained. These self-diffusion coefficients can then be used to calculate transport numbers.[150] Richardson et al.[151] measured the self-diffusion coefficients of Li ions in polymergel electrolytes by PFG-NMR. The 7Li diffusion constants obtained for the 20% PVDF/PC/LiBF4 (1.0 m) were 0.27 and 0.67 × 10−10 m2 s−1 corresponding to slow and fast-moving Li+ populations. The activation energies of 24.7 and 17.8 kJ mol−1 were obtained from Arrhenius plots for the two populations, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.4. Lithium Deposition on the Electrode Surface
sections.text:
Among all the anode materials, lithium metal has the highest volumetric and gravimetric energy density. However, electrochemical metal deposits often form nanostructured dendrites that can lead to short circuit following several electrochemical charge–discharge cycles, particularly at high rates.[154] The formation of dendrites makes this class of batteries potentially unsafe and impractical owing to the risk of fire and explosion.[155] NMR spectroscopy[154,156–158] and MRI[152,153,159–161] are used to provide real-time visualization of dendrite growth.
The skin-depth problem, due to limited penetration of radiofrequency pulses into metals, should be considered when using NMR to study Li-dendrite growth.[162] The penetration depth is also affected by the static magnetic field. For example, 6Li with a Larmor frequency of 29.4 MHz at a field strength of 4.7 T has a skin depth of 23.9 µm, whereas 7Li at a field strength of 14.1 T has a skin depth of only 8.4 µm.[154] The skin depth is almost an order of magnitude larger than the reported thickness of mossy or dendritic whiskers of 1–2 µm. As a result, the signal of the lithium microstructures can be readily separated from the signal of bulk Li, and their formation and growth can be monitored by in situ NMR spectroscopy.
Bhattacharyya et al.[154] used 7Li NMR to explore the formation lithium dendrites. A LiCoO2/Li cell with standard LiPF6containing electrolyte and symmetric Li/Li cells with ionic
liquids as electrolytes were investigated. As shown in Figure 16, the resonance at ≈258 ppm (purple lines) was attributed to the bulk lithium metal while the green line was assigned to the surface lithium species.[163] In the LiCoO2/Li cell, the intensity of the green peak grows with respect to the cycling time, indicating the accumulation of dendritic nanostructures, which could reach up to 90% of the total Li content. For a symmetric cell containing ionic liquid C4mpyrTFSI + LiTFSI, no growth of the Li microstructures was observed, even for very high currents. In 2016, Hu et al.[158] investigated the effect of the Cs+ additive on Li depositions using quantitative in situ 7Li and 133Cs NMR with planar symmetric Li cells. It was indicated that the effects of the Cs+ exhibit only at a moderate cycling current (0.25 mA) because a very small amount of Li dendrite was formed at lower cycling current (0.1 mA), while at a much higher cycling current (0.5 mA), the effect of Cs+ on the protection of the Li-metal electrode is significantly reduced.
MRI can be particularly powerful to study dendrite growth, as it provides both chemical and spatial information.[152,153,159–161] Chandrashekar et al.[152] demonstrated two- and three-dimensional 7Li MRI and magnetic-resonance chemical-shift imaging (CSI) of batteries (Figure 17). The location of the Li microstructures formed in the vicinity of the negative electrode could be revealed. Before charging, a uniformed surface can be seen for the lithium electrodes; while after charging the surface becomes rougher, suggesting the formation of dendritic structures. This is confirmed in the CSI image where signals below 270 ppm (attributed to dendrites) were observed.
In general, SSNMR and MRI can assist the assessment of materials and batteries in the following aspects: i) to detect organic and inorganic electrolyte decomposition products, such as Li2O, LiOH, lithium alkoxides, etc., in the SEI, ii) to investigate lithiation/delithiation processes; iii) to quantify the dynamics of Li ions such as Li hopping, Li diffusion, Li+ redistribution etc., iv) to monitor the lithium dendrite growth. It is worth mentioning that, in the current state, a lot of NMR research is carried out in model systems because it is difficult to observe the thin layer of SEI in real batteries. On the other hand, the cells used for in situ NMR measurements are usually quite different from common ones, which may lead to unconvincing conclusions. Nevertheless, the unique insights

sections.heading: 4.1. Core Structure of Nanocrystals
sections.text:
Platinum nanoparticles (Pt NP) have a broad array of applications in proton-exchange-membrane fuel cells, heterogeneous catalysts, nanomedicine etc.[180–182] The control of the size, shape, and composition is crucial for Pt NPs to meet different demands. 195Pt (spin = 1/2) SSNMR is extremely useful to discern the chemical-bonding environment of Pt atoms. In practice, the spectra of metals could span hundreds of kilohertz or even megahertz due to the chemical-shift anisotropy, quadrupolar coupling (for nuclei with spin quantum number greater than 1/2) and Knight shift (the effect on the nuclei resonance energy caused by conducting electrons). Achieving a uniform broadband excitation for these ultrawide patterns in the current setup of an NMR instrument is sometimes challenging. In a recent report, Rees et al.[183] used the field-sweep Fourier transform (FSFT) method to study Pt and Pt-alloy nanoparticles. Compared with conventional variable-offset cumulative frequency-stepping technique or the spin echo height spectroscopy method, the FSFT method allows a more accurate reconstruction of the 195Pt NMR pattern with improved resolution and also full automation. The authors deconvoluted the 195Pt pattern based on a cubo-octahedral model: the signal from the core and four sub-surface layers can be discerned due to their different degrees of Knight shift and local bonding symmetry. The 195Pt spin–lattice relaxation time (T1) may also be used to evaluate the conduction-band structure. For Pt nanoparticles with conducting electrons, the T1 is 66 µs; but for Pt clusters with a dozen atoms the T1 is 4 orders longer, which indicates their diamagnetic property. The authors also studied platinumalloy systems such as Pt3Al, Pt3Sc, Pt3Nb, and found that the Knight shift assumes less-negative values as the contribution of d-orbital electron increases (Al < Sc < Ti < Zr < Nb).
The recently developed WURST-CPMG (wideband uniform rate smooth truncation with Carr–Purcell–Meiboom–Gill pulses) technique[184,185] was also proven very useful for the study of ultra-wideline patterns of metals. Huang and Pruski investigated the chemical bonding of platinum in MOFs by DNP-enhanced WURST–CPMG.[186] Combined with the theoretical calculations of the magnetic-shielding tensors, they concluded that, in UIO-66-NH2, Pt2+ ions, which are coordinated to the linkers in MOFs, are in both cis- and trans- conformations, whereas only the cis- conformation was detected in the MOF-253 (Figure 18). Well-dispersed Pt nanoparticles (about 1.4 nm) supported by UIO-66-NH2 were observed in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images after the hydrogen reduction to Pt2+-impregnated UIO-66-NH2. The relative reduced population of the cis- conformation indicates that the cis- sites are less stable than the trans- ones. On the contrary, the signals of nanoparticles were not visible in the spectrum due to the >3 MHz Knight shift distribution and short relaxation times.
Quantum dots made of e.g., CdSe, CdS, InP are promising materials for the next generation of displays and lightemitting diodes (LEDs). A number of studies have been carried out to identify different atomic sites in CdSe, CdS, and InP QDs with 77Se, 113Cd, and 31P SSNMR.[187–189] Berrettini et al.[190] observed three surface selenium species in the 77Se spectra of CdSe QDs, which are assigned to vertex, edge, and facet sites, according to their chemical shifts. In a cross-polarization experiment, surface cadmium atoms obtain signal enhancement versus the core atoms, while in a directpolarization experiment, the relative intensity is proportional to the molar ratio. Recently Strouse and co-workers[192] used 77Se NMR to study the surface-to-volume ratio of selenium atoms in CdSe QDs sized from 3 nm to 7 nm. They found that the ratio agrees with the spherically truncated Wurtzite structure model expected for QDs with diameters smaller than 4 nm. This suggests that a reconstruction of the surface layers occurs for QDs smaller than 4 nm.
Due to the relatively low natural abundance and low surface concentration, the acquisition of surface 13C, 113Cd, or 77Se signals could be challenging or time-consuming for a normal SSNMR instrument. Dynamics nuclear polarization (DNP) may become a game-changing technique in this area as it can achieve signal enhancement by 2 to 3 orders of magnitude. This enhancement is crucial in detecting rare surface species and defects, and it is in particular helpful for sophisticated 2D experiments. The successful application of DNP relies on the homogeneous dispersion of a radical agent in the sample to achieve efficient polarization transfer from unpaired electrons to the nuclear spins. Recently Piveteau et al.[193] reported a strategy to maintain the homogeneity of the QD–radical mixture in the matrix of mesoporous SiO2. Using this method, they were able to get a high DNP enhancement factor of 80 (Figure 19). DNP-enhanced NMR was used to investigate the surface atoms of PbTe and CdTe QDs after they were exposed to ambient air. Tellurium oxide species were observed in the 125Te spectra of PbTe QDs, while the surface Te atoms remain unoxidized in CdTe QDs, even after long storage in air. 2D 13C–111Cd correlation experiments were also made possible by DNP, in which a correlation of the carboxyl carbon with the surface cadmium was observed. This provides direct evidence for the existence of CdX2 species at the surface of CdSe QDs. Without DNP, a
single acquisition of such a 13C–113Cd 2D spectrum would require more than 1000 days.

sections.heading: 4.2. Bonding of the Surface Ligands
sections.text:
Ligands are inseparable compartments of the nanoparticles and they determine the reactivity, stability and solubility of the nanoparticles. A number of studies have been carried out in solution to investigate the chemistry of surface ligands bonded to nanoparticles.[194–197] As the tumbling rate of nanoparticles reduces in solution, much crucial information of the surface moieties becomes invisible due to signal broadening. SSNMR is able to resolve the signals of interfacial species via magic-angle spinning and precisely target the interactions among multiple components.
Berrettini et al.[190] used 2D 1H–13C, 1H–113Cd, and 1H–77Se HETCOR experiments to characterize the configuration and site occupation of hexadecylamine (HDA) and thiophenol on the CdSe QDs surface. They observed that both the proton signals of the HDA and the thiophenol correlate with the surface cadmium in 1H–113Cd HETCOR experiments. These correlations demonstrated that both ligands bind to cadmium atoms on the QDs surface. In a 1H–77Se HETCOR experiment, a correlation of the surface selenium with the hydrocarbon chains of the HDA was also detected. Based on the observations, the authors proposed a configuration of HDA at the QD surface (Figure 20) in which the amine group of the HDA bonds to the Cd atoms, while the hydrocarbon chains tilt to the QD surface and interact with the Se vacancies. On the contrary, the authors found no tilting of the thiophenol molecules.
Reven and co-workers[198] used 13C NMR to study the dynamics of hydrocarbon ligands of different lengths at the surface of Au nanoparticles. For the methylenes at the middle of the octadecanethiol (C18) chain, the 13C signals change from 29.0 to 29.5 ppm in organic solvents to 33.5–33.8 ppm in the surface ligands. They found that the surface cysteines form a double layer, one attached to the Au surface and the other interacting with the inner layer through hydrogen bonds. Yan and Li[205] presented the possibility of π–π stacking effects of aromatic ligands appended to a the surface of gold nanoparticles, based on observation of the broadened signal in high-resolution 1H NMR.
As a brief summary, SSNMR has been playing a very important role in the study of surface structures and ligand dynamics in nanoparticles. In practice, the low concentration of surface species, the issue of paramagnetism[206] (e.g., nanoparticles with Fe, Co, Mn etc. see Supporting Information for a brief explanation), and ultrawide patterns of some quadrupolar nuclei (e.g., 197Au)[207] pose challenges for SSNMR characterization. Despite these, SSNMR can be applied to a large variety of nanocrystal materials and can explore the system via multiple angles. In addition, technical advancements, such as DNP[32–34] and ultrafast MAS,[208,209] as well as the combination with computer simulations, have made SSNMR even more powerful. We anticipate that, in the near future, SSNMR will be able to not only elucidate structures and mechanisms, but also undertake a similar role as electron microscopy and X-ray crystallography as one of the primary techniques that guide the development of nanocrystalline materials.

sections.heading: 5.1. Dynamics of Molecular Motors
sections.text:
Artificial molecular machines like molecular motors, rotors, shuttles, and switches translate the thermal energy of molecules into useful mechanical energy.[236–240] A variety of such systems are based on the relative motion of the constituent components of mechanically interlocked molecules (MIMs).[241] The engineering of such molecular machines relies on a full understanding and clever control of the molecular dynamics. SSNMR has been applied in many of the systems designed in
solid frameworks as the sole measure to determine the mode and rate of motion.[220] NMR relaxation measurements and lineshape analysis of 2H NMR are among the most powerful methods for elucidating the reorientation frequencies and the trajectories of the mobile elements. A lot of research has been carried out in this respect.[219,242–248] For example, the groups of Schurko and Loeb designed a macrocyclic rotaxane “molecular rotor” that rotates on the linkers of a MOF designated as UWDM-1.[249,250] To determine the nature of the motion, the rotaxane molecule was labeled with deuterium isotopes on its double bond and variable-temperature 2H NMR was performed as shown in Figure 21. Assisted by lineshape simulation, the authors identified four different modes of motion based on the 2H lineshape obtained from 160 to 480 K. The motion modes are clearly visualized in the Figure 21c, which depicts rotation of the macrocycle, the rocking of the CD2 group, and the combination of the two.
More recently, the same two groups reported a more advanced “molecular shuttle” in which a rotaxane moves back and forth along H-shaped organic linkers (Figure 22a) that are fixed in a MOF matrix (UWDM-4).[251] 100% enriched 13C spins

sections.heading: 5.2. Characterization of Disordered Arrangements
sections.text:
Disorder is an important feature in many hierarchal nanostructures, and in many cases, it is the major factor contributing to their properties.[253,254] For example, molecules trapped in a porous medium, ligands attached on the nanoparticle surface, and functionalities located on amorphous polymers, can each bear a certain degree of distributional disorder. However, possible arrangements, like random, clustered, or other patterns, may be embedded in the disorder. The characterization of disordered spatial arrangements remains a significant challenge and in much research the disorder has been left unexamined. Remarkably, recent studies based on SSNMR have made successful attempts to tackle this issue in a few nanostructures.
In 2010, Deng et al. invented multivariate MOFs (MTVMOFs) in which multiple functional groups are incorporated into the crystalline MOF matrix.[255] X-ray diffraction gives identical powder patterns for these MTV-MOFs with different functional groups or ratios. One of the key questions to be answered is how the functional groups are apportioned in the framework despite their disordered nature. Kong et al. pursued this using multidimensional SSNMR, in particular the REDOR technique.[256] They measured the intermolecular distances between the functional groups through 13C–15N dipolar coupling in samples with aliphatic and amine or nitro groups. The measured distance is the gauge for their later Monte Carlo simulation to determine the apportionments. For these MTV-MOFs, different apportionments, such as small clusters, random or alternating, were discovered, and the apportionment is believed to be the key to improve the CO2-adsorption properties according to their simulations. Bones are well-engineered nanocomposite materials that possess superb hardness, fracture resistance, and light weight. They are natural marvels in the eyes of chemists learning to build mechanically robust materials. In a recent study, Hu et al.[262] made an important discovery that citrate molecules are an important structuring component at the inorganic and organic interface. SSNMR was their primary technique to identify the presence of citrate molecules and also to quantify its disorder distribution on the hydroxyapatite surface. Using a series of recoupling sequences, the 13C NMR signals of different bones were scrutinized based on their proximity toward hydroxyapatite or their dynamic states. In the last part, the authors used the centerband-only detection of exchange (CODEX) technique to quantify the surface distribution of the citrate molecules, as shown in Figure 24. The CODEX technique takes advantage of 13C–13C homonuclear dipolar coupling to measure intermolecular distances.[263] The fitting of the CODEX decay curve concludes that the citrate molecules were more or less uniformly placed on the (1 0 1 0)1 and (1 0 1 0)2 planes of the hydroxyapatite crystal with a surface density of 1 molecule per 4 nm2.

sections.heading: 6. Interfaces in Nanomedicine Complexes
sections.text:
The recent advancement of nanomaterials and nanotechnology in the field of medical research has spurred a great interest in so-called “nanomedicine”.[265,266] This scientific area embraces a myriad of nanosystems whose diverse applications include monitoring techniques, early diagnostic, therapeutics, and new drug delivery and release protocols.[267] Nanomaterials studied for nanomedicine include mesoporous silicates, polymers, proteins, drug complexes, liposomes and micelles, dendrimers, emulsions, nanocrystals, carbon nanoplatforms, and quantum dots.[266–268]
One of the major challenges at the forefront of nanomedicine is to improve the efficacy of drug delivery and achieve a targeted and controlled release of the active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs). In these systems, medicines are formulated into multicomponent nanocomposites containing both APIs and various excipients acting as carriers. The interactions between the drug and the carrier are of great importance: they are the underlying factors that affect the releasing mechanisms, timing, route, and effectiveness of the treatment.[267,269] In addition, both the API and excipients may undergo a variety of physical and/or chemical changes during production processes,[269] such as granulation, grinding, milling, tablet compression, and drying.[270,271] Possible changes include the interconversion of different crystalline forms, hydrate formation, or chemical degradation. In particular, polymorphic changes of the API, may lead to significant effects on their bioactivity.[272] The stability of the drug formulations is also another fundamental requirement for pharmaceutical development and commercialization.[273] For all of these reasons, in-depth knowledge of the APIs, the excipients and their mutual interactions has profound implications and is strongly desired by the pharmaceutical industry.[267] In this regard, SSNMR has a huge potential at the forefront of both nanomedicine research and pharmaceutical industry. We will focus here mainly on the interface and host–guest analysis, which is only a very specific application of SSNMR in this area.

They first studied how ebselen interacts with the PVP-VA matrix. Separate proton environments in ebselen (aromatic) and PVP-VA (aliphatic) allow enough resolution for 1H NMR analysis with 2D homonuclear techniques (Figure 25). In the right part of the figure, the broadening of the peak at the isotropic position compared to the bulk crystalline sample is likely the result of defects in the nanocrystalline ebselen embedded in the matrix. sections.heading: 7. Interfaces in Ionomers and Graphite Oxides
7.1. Solid-State NMR of Ionomers
sections.text:
Ionomers are polymers with a certain number of ionic units, such as sulfonic acid or carboxylic acid groups. In these polymers, the neutral and ionized compartments are usually segregated into nanosized architectures, which impart them with unique properties, such as ion conductivity and selective permeability. Ionomers share the common features of soft matter, including the response to mechanical or thermal stress and ordering phenomena. Promising applications of ionomers are proton-exchange membranes for fuel cells, “artificial-muscle” actuators, reverse-osmosis membranes, and so on. In particular, Nafion, a benchmark ionomeric material developed by DuPont, receives a large amount of attention because of its outstanding proton conductivity and chemical stability. Nafion is a perfluorinated polymer that consists of a hydrophobic backbone and hydrophilic side groups which are phase-separated at the nanometer scale.[315] SSNMR has contributed exclusive insight not only to the structure and dynamics of individual phases, but also to the phenomena at the interfaces.
Early studies[316] estimated the mobility of each functional groups based on the peak width of individual 13C and 19F signals. It is found that the functional groups toward the branch points of pendant groups experience a lower degree of rotational freedom. In the following research, Chen and Schmidt-Rohr carried out more advanced SSNMR experiments that analyzed the dynamics based on 19F–13C dipolar couplings and chemical-shift anisotropy (CSA) patterns of 13C and 19F.[317] In Figure 30, the separated local field (SLF) spectra provide a quantitative measurement of 13C–19F dipolar-coupling constant. In these experiments, the horizontal dimension shows the 19F signals distinguished by their chemical shifts, while the vertical dimension shows the 19F–13C dipolar-coupling pattern corresponding to that site. In the rigid limit, the 19F–13C dipolar-coupling constant is expected to be 11.5 kHz, while the observed values are 5.9 kHz in Nafion and poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE), which the authors attributed to be a consequence of uniaxial backbone rotation. The authors also found a broader 19F–13C SLF pattern in Nafion compared to that in PTFE. Although they share the same fluoroethylene building blocks, the backbone motion in Nafion is more constrained than PTFE due to hindrance by the side branches.
The backbone dynamics of Nafion could also be quantitatively studied from the CSA patterns (Figure 31). Solid-State NMR: Solid-state NMR (SSNMR) is a spectroscopic method that applies to solid materials and also systems that are not suitable to standard solution-state NMR analysis. These materials can be either crystalline or amorphous, either organic or inorganic. One major characteristic of these solids is the anisotropic nature of the structures and microscopic interactions. The anisotropy leads to significant effects, for example broadening and crowding of NMR signals, interesting spectral patterns and different relaxation times, and it conceals a wealth of structural and dynamic information. One major task of SSNMR spectroscopists is to develop techniques (e.g., magic-angle spinning, and decou-

relaxation. To parameterize how rapidly this occurs, usually two relaxation components are considered, namely spin–lattice (T1) and spin–spin (T2) relaxation times. T1 relaxation embodies the energy-transfer process from the spin system to the surrounding lattice when the magnetization restores its initial magnitude with respect to the external magnetic field. T2 relaxation describes the process in which the spins lose coherence while processing and it reflects the entropy increase of the system. Relaxation times encode dynamics information of the molecular system.
Chemical Shift and Chemical-Shift Anisotropy: The chemical shift is directly related to the chemical environment of the nuclei as it arises from the interaction between the nuclear spin and its surrounding electron cloud. Different electronic configurations induce a variable magnetic shielding effect on the nuclei and cause the resonance frequencies to shift against each other. The shift is defined as the difference (in parts per million, ppm) between the frequency of the nucleus being observed and that of a standard compound. Mathematically, the chemical shift is described as an orientation-dependent secondrank tensor that is governed by the molecular and crystalline orientations. In solution, only the isotropic term of chemical shift is observed as the molecules are tumbling fast. However, in solids, the anisotropic part of the chemical shift interaction is also present due to restrained molecular dynamics.
Scalar Coupling: The indirect spin–spin coupling, commonly called J-coupling or scalar coupling, is a magnetic interaction between nuclei that is mediated through bonded electrons. In other words, chemical bonds must be present if scalar coupling is observed. This information is extremely useful for deciphering chemical structures and allows the development of many multidimensional correlation spectroscopies. While the scalar coupling is of great importance for solutions, in solids its effect is often masked by other stronger interactions, such as dipolar coupling. Nevertheless, some advanced SSNMR methods are able to utilize the scalar coupling to probe internuclear connectivities.
Dipolar Coupling/Interaction: Nearby nuclear spins experience each other’s magnetic dipole moment just like magnets placed together. The effective strength of the interaction strongly depends on the distance between the two spins as well as the internuclear orientation with respect to the external field and molecular dynamics. Unlike scalar coupling, dipolar coupling is a through-space interaction that does not require chemical bonds. In solutions, the dipolar coupling is mostly averaged to zero by molecular tumbling. In solids, dipolar coupling is a pronounced effect for both homonuclei (e.g., 1H–1H) and heteronuclei (e.g., 13C–1H). In SSNMR, magic-angle spinning and high-power decoupling are combined to eliminate this effect so as to achieve high-resolution spectra. On the other hand, dipolar coupling has been extensively explored by SSNMR pulse sequences to decode the internuclear distances and domain sizes of spin systems.
Quadrupolar Coupling: Due to the nonspherical distribution of electric charge in quadrupolar nuclei (i.e., nuclei with spin of >1/2), the nuclei interact with their surrounding electricfield gradient and results in the quadrupolar coupling. This effect is orientation dependent and contains rich information about the local chemical bonding structure and symmetry. In solids, the quadrupolar interaction can result in broad patterns that span tens of kilohertz or megahertz. Although many pulse
sequences successfully address the issue, the broad pattern may still be a challenge for analysis on some occasions. On the other hand, the quadrupolar interaction (e.g., 2H whose quadrupolar coupling is small) has been extensive exploited for the study of dynamics or microscopic orientations.
Paramagnetic Effect: The paramagnetic effect comes from the interaction between nuclei and unpaired electrons. As electrons have a magnetic dipole moment over 1000 times stronger than those of nuclear spins, it can dramatically alter the NMR signals nearby.[356] The effect appears mainly in two ways: by altering resonance frequencies and by increasing the relaxation rate. In some cases, the relaxation rate can be dramatically increased which renders the NMR signal undetectable. Nevertheless, this effect is used in many ways to probe structure (e.g., as contrast for magnetic resonance imaging) or to enhance NMR signal (e.g., in the dynamic nuclear polarization technique.[32–34])
Powder Pattern: The NMR interactions, including chemicalshift interaction, dipolar coupling, and quadrupolar coupling are anisotropic and they give rise to different frequencies according to different molecular orientations. A multitude of molecular orientations are present in solids of powder or polycrystalline form, resulting in a distribution of frequencies in the SSNMR signal. This produces a broad, yet characteristic, spectral profile designated as the powder pattern. Powder patterns encompass rich geometric information and are also dependent on molecular dynamics. Relatively simple patterns are preferred experimental data for modeling and simulations, but crowded patterns can make NMR signals obscure. To this end, the magic-angle spinning technique was developed to remove or alleviate anisotropic effect so as to increase spectral resolution.
Magic-Angle Spinning: Magic-angle spinning (MAS) is a technique used in SSNMR that can dramatically increase the spectroscopic resolution. It eliminates or reduces the anisotropic effect in solid samples by spinning the sample at a set angle (i.e., the magic angle of 54.74°) with respect to the external field. If the spinning rate is fast enough, the effects of chemical-shift anisotropy, dipolar coupling, and part of quadrupolar coupling can be averaged to zero. In practice, the MAS rate is sometimes not sufficient to overcome the anisotropic effect due to various limitations. Residual peaks (i.e., spinning side bands) can occur at positions away from the isotropic center with separations equivalent to multiples of the spinning rate. MAS rates range from 0.1 to 110 kHz can be achieved with current design of hardware, and the upper limit has been pushed further in recent years.[357]
Cross Polarization: Cross polarization (CP) is a technique that transfers the polarization from abundant nuclei (e.g., protons with 100% natural abundance) to rare nuclei (e.g., carbon-13 with 1% natural abundance) through their dipolar interactions. It can substantially increase the signal of the rare spin systems and may also be used as a filter to select signals in close contact with the abundant spins. An added benefit when considering 1H–13C CP experiments is that the shorter relaxation time of protons allows more signal averaging with the same amount of experimental time. The combination of CP with MAS represents a routine experiment that is performed in SSNMR, but the quantification with CP needs to be careful as the polarization-transfer efficiency is generally non-equivalent for different species.

Decoupling Sequences: In the solid state, strong dipolar coupling among heteronuclei (e.g., 13C–1H) or homonuclei (usually 1H–1H) may result in significant signal broadening, thus reducing the spectral resolution. Decoupling sequences are a series of r.f. pulse sequences that manipulate the spin systems in order to suppress the dipolar coupling effect and achieve high resolution spectra.
Recoupling Sequences: Recoupling sequences are a series of pulse sequences used to selectively reintroduce the anisotropy features preventing them being averaged out by MAS. These sequences are usually programmed in multidimensional experiments to measure the interatomic distance, reveal intermolecular correlations, and uncover related structural and dynamics information.
Two-Dimensional (2D) Correlation Spectroscopy: In NMR spectroscopy, a second spectral dimension is often introduced to assist the elucidation of the one-dimensional signal through the chemical-bond or spatial connectivity. It can also provide additional information such as dynamics, orientation distributions, or even the multiple quantum signals that are inaccessible in one-dimensional spectra. On the other hand, magnetic-field gradients are introduced intentionally to separate the resonance frequency of spins along the direction of gradient. This method lays the foundation of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), in which the 3D spatial location of spins is mapped via their field-dependent frequencies. In some liquid-state and solid-state NMR probes, the gradient function is also a powerful option for measuring translational diffusion or for coherence selection. Pulsed-field gradient (PFG) NMR is such a technique, in which the molecular displacement and thus the site-specific diffusion coefficient is measured by controlled durations of gradients.
Dynamic Nuclear Polarization: Dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) is a technique that transfers the large Boltzmann polarization of electron spins to nuclear spins. It can boost the NMR signals by several orders of magnitude and reduce the acquisition time dramatically.[32–34] It has thrived in recent years in

sections.heading: 9. Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
Here, we have covered some of the methods in SSNMR spectroscopy that are applied to the investigation of nanomaterials of contemporary interest. We have focused our topics on the characterization of interfacial chemistry, which includes interfaces between hybrid and multiphase components, interfaces for electrochemical processes, and interfaces for chemical reactions. In-depth characterization at the molecular level of such systems has been proven to be important for the understanding of mechanisms, the elucidation of extrinsic properties, and the refining of preparation methods. SSNMR is well-suited to performing these challenging tasks and has therefore emerged as a valuable characterization tool, although in the field of nanomaterials its capabilities and applications are still far from being fully realized. There are many more systems that are not included here, but can still be studied by SSNMR, for example, materials for photochemical processes,[358] biomaterials,[359] hydrogels,[360] carbon nanomaterials,[361,362] 2D materials,[363] and some biologically relevant systems.[364,365] Also, SSNMR can be applied at multiple investigation levels; e.g., for the characterization of structures, the study of dynamic motions, and the monitoring of kinetic chemical processes.
From the technical point of view, SSNMR methods have been progressing steadily in recent years and continue to open up new possibilities. The resolution, sensitivity, and applicability of SSNMR have improved owing to the following facts: i) the availability of much higher external static magnetic fields (e.g., commercial magnets of 1.2 GHz i.e., 28.2 T are currently in production[366]), ii) faster sample spinning (e.g., ultrafast MAS of more than 110 kHz),[367,368] iii) effective decoupling methods for improved spectroscopic resolution,[369–372] iv) development of multidimensional correlation sequences,[20,373] v) high-resolution techniques for half-integer quadrupolar nuclei such as MQMAS,[374,357,375] vi) development of hardware for in situ measurements (e.g., in situ battery testing, in situ catalysis,[27–29,376]) and vii) signal-enhancement techniques, such as dynamic nuclear polarization.[32–34] In addition, SSNMR is often successfully combined with quantum-mechanical and molecular-dynamics simulations in order to interpret spectroscopic features.[377,378]
Nevertheless, it is also necessary for researchers to be aware of the limitation of SSNMR: its relatively low sensitivity. For most NMR labs, milligram-level of samples or equivalently micromolar quantities of nuclei spins are still required. DNP or other hyperpolarization methods may be able to push this limit down by another two or three orders of magnitude,[32] but these are not always available in common SSNMR labs. We anticipate that the surge of nanotechnology will bring new prospects for SSNMR, as well as other characterization techniques, for them to improve and evolve in a rapid manner.
Lastly, we resonate with a quote from Advanced Materials editorin-chief Peter Gregory: “the nature of today’s materials science is such that the interaction of experts from different fields is not only important but quite often essential”.[379] We believe that “human factors”, i.e. the innovative adaptation of these techniques and interdisciplinary intellectual exchange, are the keys for the successful utilization of SSNMR in the research of nanomaterials.
